objtitle.title: *Henry III, from the Wall-Painting in the Sedilia above the Monument of King Sebert*

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe work is numbered "III." in pencil top right.

provenance.name: Society of Antiquaries, London
provenance.note: The Society of Antiquaries commissioned Blake's engraving master, James Basire, to execute this drawing. Basire assigned Blake to this task. The drawing was presumably delivered to the Society shortly after its engraving for Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, first published by the Society of Antiquaries in 1780.

desc.objtitle: Henry III, from the Wall-Painting in the Sedilia above the Monument of King Sebert, Object 1 (BUT9)

objnote.p: The collection stamp of the Society of Antiquaries appears bottom center left below the design. A larger, circular collection stamp of the Society appears lower right. A water color replica (Butlin 17) of this water color is in the Bodleian Library, Oxford. An engraving of this design was published in Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, Plate 5 (1780), and in *Vetusta Monumenta*, volume 2 of c. 1789, Plate 33.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design, part of the wall painting in the sedilia above King Sebert's monument at Westminster Abbey, is a panel with a patterned background and a narrow border, which contains beveling, two columns, and a plain arch. Inside the arch are four points of a decorative tracery, each containing a gilded trefoil design and terminating in a leaf. The two points nearest the arch's top are smaller and more compressed. In the center of the arching panel is a crowned man who represents King Henry III. The wears a long-sleeved gown, a decorative belt or cord, a floor-length robe, and a leaved crown. He has short, curly hair and slight evidence of stubble or short facial hair. He faces forward, but his head turns to the left with his eyes looking in that direction. He wears ornate gloves and rings on both hands. His left arm is bent at the elbow and raised to the left, where he points with his left hand. His right arm is bent and at his side; his right hand holds a scepter over his right shoulder.

component.illusobjdesc: The design represents the wall-painting of King Henry III in the sedilia above King Sebert's monument in Westminster Abbey. The gray background of the design may suggest stone and the tracery around the top of the arch may be gilded.

The design represents the wall-painting of King Henry III in the sedilia above King Sebert's monument in Westminster Abbey. It depicts a tall, narrow painted panel that includes a narrow border, the lower portion of which suggests a beveled design. Forming the sides of this border are the inside halves of two columns or pillars; the left column bears a cross-hatched design, and the right appears to be segmented. The arching upper portions of this border are plain, but inside the arch are four points of a decorative tracery, each containing a gilded trefoil design and terminating in a leaf.The two points nearest the arch's top are smaller and more compressed.
Each of the four points of the decorative tracery near the top of the design appears to end in a decorative leaf.
A pattern of small golden lions that all face to the left is visible against the grey, stone(?) background of the painted panel.

In the center of the painted panel is the figure of Henry III. He wears a long-sleeved, floor-length gown secured at the waist with a decorative belt or cord. A hooded robe with an ornate border covers his shoulders but remains open in front. King Henry wears a leaved crown atop short, curly hair. His chin bears slight evidence of stubble or short facial hair. The wrinkles on his forehead suggest a furrowed brow. He faces forward, but his head turns to the left with his eyes looking in that direction. His left arm is at his side and bent upward and left. He points toward the left with his raised left hand. His fingers are spread, showing a ring on his fifth finger. On both hands, he wears gloves bearing large diamond-shaped emblems and decorative borders. His right arm is bent slightly at his side, and his right gloved hand (also showing a ring on the fifth finger) holds a scepter that extends over (and may rest on) his right shoulder.
King Henry III holds a scepter in his right hand.
King Henry's crown and the upper end of his scepter are decorated with golden leaves.

phystext.p: III.This pencil inscription was probably not written by Blake.

foot IThis inscription and line 3, both in pen and ink, record the height of the design. They are written vertically along the right side of the design. These inscription were probably not written by Blake.
Basire. del.This pen and ink inscription, a reference to or signature of Blake's engraving master James Basire, was probably not written by Blake.
foot IThis inscription and line 6, both in pen and ink, record the width of the design. These inscriptions were probably not written by Blake.

Figure supposed to be that of Henry III. as painted on the N. front of the Monument of King Sebert in Westmr. Abbey. Vetust. Mon. VolThis pen and ink inscription is probably not by Blake. "Vetust. Mon. Vol" (with any further inscription trimmed off by the right edge of the leaf) is a reference to volume 2 of *Vetusta Monumenta*, published by the Society of Antiquaries c. 1789. An engraving of this design, signed by Blake's engraving master James Basire, was published as plate 33 in that volume.
